publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

msIdentifier.repository: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

seg.seg: [excessive] sweating, inflammation, reddening, oral malodor, moisture, bad digestion, disorder of the body fluids, delirious speech, fainting, dizziness [and] jaundice [lit. being yellow] [are] the symptoms of bile [diseases],
Sanskrit 113. Paleness, [feeling of] coldness, [feeling of] heaviness, itching, greasiness of the body, steadiness,

infection of the respiratory tract, rejection [of mucus] and accumulation [of mucus], and also impairment of reaction [lit. acting slowly], [these are] the symptoms of phlegma [diseases], said the wise ones. 113. Sanskrit

symptoms induced by that [= the preceding three elements] [belong] even to all diseases which have the same name. Some other difference does exist for these ones because of which they receive [lit. go to, shift to] a [specific] name and another [cure]. 114.
Exhaustion, sleepiness, non-purity of the heart, the development of vicious elements, the absence of hunger, the heaviness of belly,
disgust, drowsiness, they [the wise ones] say that the [preceding] disease is bound with the absence of digestion,— and also the [excessive] urge to urinate. 115. Sanskrit
by fasting [lit. food to be rejected], by sesame oil, by salty [or] sweet food [and] drinks; the bile [disease is cured] exactly in the same way (by) sweet [or] bitter decoctions.

p.note: The leaf number is written in the string hole space.

The Tocharian translation does not correspond to the Sanskrit text, which is corrupt. The original passage refers to the three elements wind, bile, and phlegma that induce diseases. Each disease has an individual proper name and in addition a second name referring to the prevalence of symptoms that are characteristic of one of the three elements like Skt. vātaja- 'generated from wind'; see 43-44. The Tocharian text, however, by itself transports the genuine sense, so that one may surmise it reflects an oral commentary transmitted independently of the written transmission.
Above the last akṣara of mamauñempa one sees a dot, which is a blotch rather than an anusvāra.

list.item: Bibliothèque nationale de France, fonds Pelliot Koutchéen (Paris)

b4. Above the last akṣara of mamauñempa one sees a dot, which is a blotch rather than an anusvāra.

b1. The Tocharian translation does not correspond to the Sanskrit text, which is corrupt. The original passage refers to the three elements wind, bile, and phlegma that induce diseases. Each disease has an individual proper name and in addition a second name referring to the prevalence of symptoms that are characteristic of one of the three elements like Skt. vātaja- 'generated from wind'; see [[Filliozat 1948]]: 43-44. The Tocharian text, however, by itself transports the genuine sense, so that one may surmise it reflects an oral commentary transmitted independently of the written transmission.

Edition and complete translation: [[Lévi 1911a]]: 128-129; [[Filliozat 1948]]: 36-37, 42-45, 47-48; [[Carling 2003a]].
Corrections of Filliozat's edition: [[Sieg 1955]]: 64-67.

a1 harāgadaurgandhya saṃkledavipākaśothā pralāpamūrcchyā bhramapītabhāvā karmāṇi pittasya vadanti tadñā 100-10-2 || t_s_arśalñe syā a2 lñe _p_alśalñe • _r_atrauñe yolo were_t_s_aṃññe waiwalñe • pkelñe ywerū welñe : pit maiwalñe waiwalau tute nesalñe pittantse ṣotruna a3 weskeṃ aiśaumyi 100-10-2 ○ || śvetatvaśītatvagurūtvakaṇḍasnehopadehastimitatvalepā utsedasaṃghātacirakri a4 yāś ca kaphasya karmā○ṇi vadanti tadñā 100-10-3 || arkwiññe krośśaññe • kramart_s_aṃññe saiwe ṣmarñe kektseñäntse po po a5 _k_aṃntse lauwalñe tarkalñe • kraupalñentse _ṣ_p\ : walke yamalñe _ṣ_p_a leśpantse ṣotruna weñāre aiśaumyi 100-10-3 || etāni liṅgāni a6 ca tatkṛtāni sarvāmayānām api rcaikanāmāś cid bhavet\• prāptiviśeṣam eṣāṃ sajñaṃtaraṃ yena ca saṃprayāti 100-10-4 || toyä\ ṣo b1 truna _ṣ_p_a tuntse yāmuwa po tekanmat_s\• rano ṣe-ñe_m\•mat_s\• : su ksa _m_aske_t_a_r\ wāki cainat_s\• ñe_m\•ne alyekne _ṣ_p\• cesa yaneṃ 100-10-4 b2 || ālasyatantrihṛdayo viśuddhidoṣapravṛtti kṣudabhāvamūtrai gurūdaratvārucisuptatābhir āmānvitaṃ tadviduṣā vadanti 100- b3 10-5 || alā_s_aṃññe ṣpane ○ aramśne mā asta_r_aṃñe nakanmat_s\• ecce spārtalñe • kestantse mā nesalñe • kramart_s_añe kasāntse a b4 ruci klantsalñe mamauñempa ○ ritto_ṣ\• teki weskeṃ : śo[ntsau]ñe _ṣ_p_a 100-10-5 || sniktoṣṇatailalavaṇāmblamadhurānnapānaiḥ pi b5 ttaṃ tathā madhuratiktakaṣāyaśītai śleṣmaṃ kaṭūṣṇakaṣāyarukṣair āmaṃ praśāntim upayāty apatarpaṇaiś ca 100-10-6 || yente ta b6 rkallonasa kuñci_t_aṣṣana ṣalywesa : salyitsana swarona śwatsanma yoktsanmasa pi_t\• _m_andrākka swarona _r_askarona kaṣāynta

a1 |harāgadaurgandhya |saṃkledavipākaśothā |pralāpamūrcchyā |bhramapītabhāvā |karmāṇi |pittasya |vadanti |tadñā 112 || tsärśalñe syālñe|syā|lñe a2 pälśalñe • rätrauñe yolo weretsäṃññe waiwalñe • pkelñe ywerū welñe : pit maiwalñe waiwalau tute nesalñe pittantse ṣotruna a3 weskeṃ aiśaumyi 112 || |śvetatvaśītatvagurūtvakaṇḍasnehopadehastimitatvalepā |utsedasaṃghātacirakri- a4 |yāś |ca |kaphasya |karmāṇi |vadanti |tadñā 113 || arkwiññe krośśaññe • kramartsäṃññe saiwe ṣmarñe kektseñäntse po «†po» a5 käṃntse lauwalñe tarkalñe • kraupalñentse ṣp : walke yamalñe ṣpä leśpantse ṣotruna weñāre aiśaumyi 113 || |etāni |liṅgāni a6 |ca |tatkṛtāni |sarvāmayānām |api |rcaikanāmā«ka»ś |cid |bhavet |prāptiviśeṣam |eṣāṃ |sajñaṃtaraṃ |yena |ca |saṃprayāti 114 || toy ṣotruna|ṣo|truna b1 ṣpä tuntse yāmuwa po tekanmaṃts|tekanmats rano ṣe-ñemnaṃts|ṣe-ñemmats : su ksa mäsketär wāki cainaṃts|cainats ñemne alyekne ṣp cesa yaneṃ 114 b2 || |ālasyatantrihṛdayo |viśuddhidoṣapravṛtti |kṣudabhāvamūtrai |gurūdaratvārucisuptatābhir |āmānvitaṃ |tadviduṣā |vadanti 115|100-|10-5 b3 || alāsäṃññe ṣpane aramśne mā astaräññe|astaräṃñe nakanmaṃts|nakanmats ecce spārttalñe|spārtalñe • kestantse mā nesalñe • kramartsäñe ka«t»sāntse aruci|a|ruci b4 klantsalñe mamauñempa rittoṣ teki weskeṃ : śontsauñe ṣpä 115 || |sniktoṣṇatailalavaṇāmblamadhurānnapānaiḥ |pi- b5 |ttaṃ |tathā |madhuratiktakaṣāyaśītai |śleṣmaṃ |kaṭūṣṇakaṣāyarukṣair |āmaṃ |praśāntim |upayāty |apatarpaṇaiś |ca 116 || yente tarkallonasa|ta|rkallonasa b6 kuñcitäṣṣana ṣalywesa : salyitsana swarona śwatsanma yoktsanmasa pit mändrākka swarona räskarona kaṣāynta

The leaf number is written in the string hole space.

a1 Sanskrit 112. Fatigue, a2 [excessive] sweating, inflammation, reddening, oral malodor, moisture, bad digestion, disorder of the body fluids, delirious speech, fainting, dizziness [and] jaundice [lit. being yellow] [are] the symptoms of bile [diseases], a3 say the wise ones. 112. Sanskrit a4 Sanskrit 113. Paleness, [feeling of] coldness, [feeling of] heaviness, itching, greasiness of the body, steadiness, a5 infection of the respiratory tract, rejection [of mucus] and accumulation [of mucus], and also impairment of reaction [lit. acting slowly], [these are] the symptoms of phlegma [diseases], said the wise ones. 113. Sanskrit a6 Sanskrit And these b1 symptoms induced by that [= the preceding three elements] [belong] even to all diseases which have the same name. Some other difference does exist for these ones because of which they receive [lit. go to, shift to] a [specific] name and another [cure]. 114. b2 Sanskrit 115 b3 Exhaustion, sleepiness, non-purity of the heart, the development of vicious elements, the absence of hunger, the heaviness of belly, b4 disgust, drowsiness, they [the wise ones] say that the [preceding] disease is bound with the absence of digestion,— and also the [excessive] urge to urinate. 115. Sanskrit b5 Sanskrit The wind [disease is cured] b6 by fasting [lit. food to be rejected], by sesame oil, by salty [or] sweet food [and] drinks; the bile [disease is cured] exactly in the same way (by) sweet [or] bitter decoctions.
